articles.headline: Prosecutors’ Winning Streak on Insider Trading Cases Ends
articles.snippet: The younger brother of the convicted inside trader Raj Rajaratnam was found not guilty at his own trial, a rare loss for federal prosecutors.
articles.abstract: The younger brother of the convicted inside trader Raj Rajaratnam was found not guilty at his own trial, a rare loss for federal prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scene that played out over and over again in Lower Manhattan in recent years — federal prosecutors enter the courtroom with an insider trading case and leave with a conviction — all began in 2007 with a tip about a little-known hedge fund trader, Rengan Rajaratnam.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Ben Protess and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, Goal, and Brazil’s Day Goes Dark
articles.snippet: Few would have envisioned the home team, so close to glory, being so thoroughly overmatched as in the 7-1 semifinal loss to Germany.
articles.abstract: Few would have envisioned the home team, so close to glory, being so thoroughly overmatched as in the 7-1 semifinal loss to Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — The fireworks began at dawn. All around this city, loud pops and bangs rang out as men and women and children, so many dressed in yellow, set off flares and beeped car horns. It was supposed to be a magical day. The Brazilian national soccer team, playing at home, was one game away from a World Cup final.

articles.headline: Blueprints for Taming the Climate Crisis
articles.snippet: A report explores the technological paths available for the 15 main economies to maintain growth and cut carbon emissions enough to prevent climatic havoc.
articles.abstract: A report explores the technological paths available for the 15 main economies to maintain growth and cut carbon emissions enough to prevent climatic havoc.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s what your future will look like if we are to have a shot at preventing devastating climate change.

articles.headline: Profits Vanish in Venezuela After Currency Devaluation
articles.snippet: An overvalued bolívar meant the country had been a major source of profits for foreign firms, but they evaporated for many with a new exchange rate.
articles.abstract: An overvalued bolívar meant the country had been a major source of profits for foreign firms, but they evaporated for many with a new exchange rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Brink’s, the armored car company, could see about $400 million in revenue disappear this year from its operations in this country. Procter & Gamble announced a write-down of $275 million on its Venezuela business. American Airlines and Delta Air Lines are slashing their Venezuela flights.

articles.headline: Faith Groups Seek Exclusion From Bias Rule
articles.snippet: President Obama is facing mounting pressure from religious groups demanding to be excluded from an executive order that would bar discrimination against gay people by companies that do government work.
articles.abstract: President Obama is facing mounting pressure from religious groups demanding to be excluded from an executive order that would bar discrimination against gay people by companies that do government work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a setback in the Supreme Court in the Hobby Lobby case, President Obama is facing mounting pressure from religious groups demanding to be excluded from his long-promised executive order that would bar discrimination against gay men and lesbians by companies that do government work.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: For Crumbs, Growth May Have Come Too Fast
articles.snippet: Crumbs shut down Monday, a week after Nasdaq suspended trading of the company’s shares because, it said, the retailer did not meet requirements for market capitalization, net profit or shareholder equity.
articles.abstract: Crumbs shut down Monday, a week after Nasdaq suspended trading of the company’s shares because, it said, the retailer did not meet requirements for market capitalization, net profit or shareholder equity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Word went out swiftly through Midtown Manhattan skyscrapers, downtown coffee shops and clusters of snack-craving children heading home from day camp.

articles.headline: Spying Case Left Obama in Dark, U.S. Officials Say
articles.snippet: When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel last Thursday, he did not know that a German intelligence operative had been arrested a day earlier, and had admitted to passing secrets to the C.I.A.
articles.abstract: When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel last Thursday, he did not know that a German intelligence operative had been arrested a day earlier, and had admitted to passing secrets to the C.I.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany last Thursday, he had a busy agenda: to consult with a close ally and to mobilize wavering Europeans to put more pressure on Russia to end its covert incursions in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Mark Landler

articles.headline: American Apparel Deal Gives Retailer a Lifeline
articles.snippet: The company is to remake its board and to keep its manufacturing in the United States.
articles.abstract: The company is to remake its board and to keep its manufacturing in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a bruising three-week battle over the future of American Apparel, the struggling retailer reached a deal with its largest shareholders on Wednesday, agreeing to remake its board and to try to shore up the company’s finances.

articles.headline: On the Road to Samarra, Glimpses of Iraq’s New Fractured Reality
articles.snippet: With the threat of Sunni militants looming, various Shiite militias have planted flags and claimed spheres of influence on the 75-mile stretch from Baghdad to Samarra.
articles.abstract: With the threat of Sunni militants looming, various Shiite militias have planted flags and claimed spheres of influence on the 75-mile stretch from Baghdad to Samarra.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAMARRA, Iraq — About 20 miles beyond the northern gates of Baghdad, on the way to the embattled city of Samarra, site of one of Shiite Islam’s holiest shrines, the road empties out as if some invisible barrier has been passed.
